(This is all in response to the larger dumb argument that gas prices are high because of gouging or some other domestic [private sector] market manipulation. It’s a simple answer that ignores every aspect of how fuel sales, retail, or, commodities work.) (2/2)

Some gas stations may sell fuel below-cost (at a loss) for price rivalry with adjacent stations. Generally, stations break-even at best on fuel sales, and any gas station profit comes from either co-located/owned retail (as noted below) or food/beverage/tobacco/etc sales. (1/2) https://twitter.com/blooshier/status/1466757494223613952 QT @Blooshier @farrellbruce2 @RepMeijer Costco isn’t selling at a loss, but they don’t need the margins on the price of the gas, as the gas increases store visits and thus profits.

B/c of my ASAP Act in the infrastructure package, we'll work to make our nation's transit stations more accessible—making traveling so much easier for so many and pushing our nation closer to that more perfect Union our founders envisioned. Please share! https://www.chicagotribune.com/politics/ct-chicago-infrastructure-bill-accessible-transit--20211202-wfq7exxmrjfqxigknxqc3zwvhu-story.html

The truth is that *everyone* who is able-bodied, whether they realize it or not, can be just one moment away from needing accessible options to help them get to work, to school, to their families and friends.

That's why the Bipartisan Infrastructure Deal is a BFD.

That experience—of being unable to independently get around—is humiliating. And it limits our freedom to pursue certain jobs, access necessary services or enjoy basic conveniences that most Americans don’t think twice about.

But hey. Disabilities do not discriminate.

Like many, I spend a lot of time planning how to get from point A to point B. Places will say they are accessible, but if they have inclines a bit too steep or an entrance a few inches too high—it can prevent those of us in wheelchairs from being able to access it w/o assistance.

The ADA was signed into law 30+ years ago, yet so many Americans don’t realize how many barriers still exist and how difficult it still is for the disability community to fully participate in society.

On International Day of Persons with Disabilities, let's talk about it.👇

This bill strengthens privacy protections + security measures for those state-maintained databases to ensure no personally identifiable information is included or shared with the federal government.  If you want information or to read the text of the bill, please call my office. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FFucUheXEAgiZc_.jpg

It also does not give the federal government access to your vaccine records.  The bill is addressing state vaccine databases that have been in existence for decades to help monitor public health  (they hold aggregate data for all types of vaccines).

There is a great deal of misinformation circulating regarding a vote on HR 550.  Contrary to some news reports, this bill had nothing to do with creating a federal database or imposing a federal vaccine mandate.
